factoid: Bilíbin is going.

Prince Andrew says that Bilíbin should be a consistent philosopher.
Prince Andrew says that Bilíbin should look at the other side of the question.
Prince Andrew says that Bilíbin's duty is to take care of himself.
Prince Andrew says that Bilíbin has not been ordered to return.
Prince Andrew says that Bilíbin has not been dismissed from here.
Prince Andrew says that Bilíbin can stay and go with us wherever our ill luck takes us.
Prince Andrew says that we are going to Olmütz.
Prince Andrew says that Olmütz is a very decent town.
Prince Andrew says that Bilíbin and Prince Andrew will travel comfortably in Prince Andrew's calèche.
Bolkónski says that Bilíbin should stop joking.
Bolkónski says that he is speaking sincerely as a friend.
Bolkónski says that Bilíbin should consider where and why he is going.
Bolkónski says that Bilíbin might remain here.
Bolkónski says that Bilíbin is faced by one of two things.
Bolkónski says that either Bilíbin will not reach his regiment before peace is concluded, or Bilíbin will share defeat and disgrace with Kutúzov's whole army.
Bilíbin feels that the dilemma is insoluble.
Prince Andrew says that he cannot argue about it.
Prince Andrew thinks that he is going to save the army.
Bilíbin says that Prince Andrew is a hero.
Bolkónski set off to rejoin the army.
Bolkónski did not know where he would find the army.
Bolkónski feared that he would be captured by the French on the way to Krems.
Bolkónski had taken leave of the Minister of War.
In Brünn everybody attached to the court was packing up.
In Brünn the heavy baggage was already being dispatched to Olmütz.
Near Hetzelsdorf Prince Andrew struck the high road.
The Russian army was moving with great haste and in great disorder along the high road.
The road was obstructed with carts, making it impossible to get by in a carriage.
Prince Andrew took a horse from a Cossack commander.
Prince Andrew took a Cossack from a Cossack commander.
Prince Andrew was hungry and weary.
Prince Andrew rode past the baggage wagons in search of the commander in chief and his own luggage.
Very sinister reports of the position of the army reached Prince Andrew.
The appearance of the troops in their disorderly flight confirmed these rumors.
Prince Andrew remembered Bonaparte's words.
Prince Andrew felt astonishment at the genius of his hero.
Prince Andrew felt wounded pride.
Prince Andrew felt hope of glory.
Prince Andrew thought that if there was nothing left but to die.
Prince Andrew thought that if need be, he would do it no worse than others.
Prince Andrew said that the Russian army which has been brought from the ends of the earth by English gold will share the same fate as the army at Ulm.
Prince Andrew looked with disdain at the endless confused mass of detachments, carts, guns, artillery, baggage wagons, and vehicles.
From all sides there was rattle of wheels, creaking of carts and gun carriages, tramp of horses, crack of whips, shouts, urging of horses, and swearing of soldiers, orderlies, and officers.
Along the sides of the road fallen horses were seen.
Some fallen horses were flayed.
Some fallen horses were not flayed.
Broken-down carts had solitary soldiers waiting.
Soldiers were straggling from their companies.
Crowds set off to neighboring villages or returned from them dragging sheep, fowls, hay, and bulging sacks.
At each ascent or descent of the road crowds were denser.
The din of shouting was more incessant.
Soldiers floundering knee-deep in mud pushed guns and wagons.
Whips cracked.
Hoofs slipped.
Traces broke.
Lungs were strained with shouting.
Officers directing the march rode backward and forward between the carts.
Officers' voices were feebly heard amid the uproar.
Officers despaired of the possibility of checking the disorder.
